review_blob: Cloudy orange, soft white head releasing light floral aroma.  Medium bitterness with some muted sweetness.  Really good malt flavor with easy going hop character.  Easy drinking, fun kind of beer.

Glass fills with copper nectar, topped by a creamy, rocky off-white crown of glorious foam.  Citrus and pepper in the bready aroma.  Literally bursting with flavor - solid barley malt support for the spicy rye and generous portion of citrus hops.  This earthy ,rich concoction will command the drinkers undivided attention long after the lingering bitter finish.  My favorite SN brew.

OK.  Big improvement over the cheap pale lagers.  It has flavor, hard to describe but not offensive.  Medium body appropriately carbonated.  Alcohol not detected by senses, but halfway through makes itself well known.  Overall, not bad, but not really something to write home about either.  I would choose this over B/M/C lagers anytime.

Very cloudy light golden pour, 2 finger creamy white head.  Head diminishes to about half, then sticks around to the final shaking-out-the-last-drop.  Moderate+  hoppy aroma mostly grapefruit and lemon.  Taste is hop bitterness, orange, coriander with soft malt backbone.  Very light body, lively carbonation, bitter dry finish.  A very nice outside-the-box surprise from Saranac.  If I could change one thing, I would add a bit more malt and a cat hair less carbonation, but very good as is!  (OK, that was two things.)

Dull hazy amber pour, fluffy white head.  Aroma of earthy, spicy hops, along with toasted malt.  Flavor is more of the same - much more!  Abundant hops are very smoothly blended into the toasted malt base producing big flavor yet somehow not overpowering.  A tightly woven tapestry of aroma and flavor.

I was really looking forward to this one.  Any expectations I held were immediately snuffed out with the first sip.  It seems to be a pale lager with just enough roasted malt to color it - which is very little.  What is "cold-brewed", anyway??  Very thin body, very abrupt finish.  May be a passable "lawnmower beer", except for the price.
Copper pour, short-lived head, dense sticky lacing.  Interesting aroma - warm bread and creamsicle.   Good malt base holds up the hoppiness well.  Very bitter but never harsh.   Highly recommended.

Deep golden pour, short head dininishing to thin persistent covering.  Aroma of bread, cereal malt  with spicy floral hops.  Taste of sweet toasty malt precisely balanced with German noble hops.  Light body with nicely bitter finish.  Big flavor for a relatively simple brew.  This was much better than expected and I would definitely buy again.

Deep brown, nearly black pour with rocky 2 finger tan head, slowly receding.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate/coffee prominent.  Earthy character.  Taste same as aroma but more so.  Full body is very satisfying sitting by a fire on a cold night.  Lingering roasty finish begs for another - well done.

Deep, clear copper pour with substantial creamy head, slowly dissipating.  Aroma of hay, caramel and toasted malts backed by a spicy hop addition.  Taste is medium sweet, medium bitter, bold yet smooth.  Medium body with subtle alcohol tang, lasting bitterness into the finish.  I find this a very interesting and drinkable Octoberfest, getting better as the nights get cooler.  Two thumbs up!

Deep copper pour, yielding a 2-finger very creamy off white head.  Clen earthy hop aroma.  Taste of brown/chocolate/crystal malts, very nice mix.  Medium-light palate, average carbonation, nice chocolaty finish.

Cloudy amber pour with 1-finger lasting off white head.  Big resin/grass/sitrus aroma -exactly like fresh hop pellets when you first cut open the bag.  Medium heavy bitterness somewhat balanced by caramel malts.  Medium body, sticky texture.  Average carbonation with pleasantly lasting bitter hop finish.  Overall, I love this beer!  Big, bold and very well crafted.

Pours reddish copper, slightly hazy.  Very dense creamy head, dark beige in color, yielding solid aroma of resinous earthy hops against strong toasty/caramel backdrop.  Some citrus in the complex matrix.  Taste is very bitter without being harsh at all.  Full body, creamy sticky texture, average carbonation with Loooong bitter finish.  Very dense substantial brew.  Much more like a food than a drink.  Absolutely delicious.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada 30th Anniversary Our Brewers Reserve Grand Cru

review_blob: Just like the commercial deScription says.  Very light and refreshing.  Light fruity aroma, cloudy golden,pour  fluffy head.  Malty toward bready, as expected.  Perhaps the most agreeable wheat beer I have had to date.
Hop heads delight.  Solid caramel malt with a thick blanket of citrus/pine hop goodness.  One literally begs for the next one.  Medium body with sticky texture, long bitter finish.  Delicious.

Very dark brown pour with largish light tan rocky head.  Roasty aroma, very sweet malt, chocolate, brown sugar.  Incredible taste, first sip slightly buckled the knees. Sweet caramel, chocolate, roasted malt with touch of burnt sugar.  Medium-full palate, appropriate bitterness.  A dream come true!

Bottle.  Nice burnt amber pour, average off white head.  Aroma of pine and citrus hops, laid over a sweet maltiness.  Taste is same but stronger, medium body with nice lingering finish.  I would gladly buy this one again.
Draft.  Malty with little hop taste or aroma.  A good beer, just not too exciting.

Deep burnt orange fills the glass, topped by a lingering film of soft eggshell foam.  Rich grapefruit meets the nose, overpowering whatever else lies beneath.  Taste of piney citrus, rich toasty/roasty malt goodness with a certain residual sweetness.  Ethereal ethanol dances just within the range of perception, with promises of happy dreams.  A well balanced concoction that is sure to be regular guest at mi casa.

Hazy amber pour, big puffy off-white head yielding heavenly spicy aromas of floral and citrus hops.  Big taste of spicy sweet malt, big bitterness overcoming the sweetness.  Full body, thick oily texture, average carbonation.  Long bitter finish.  A tremendous brew, at 5 bucks and change (25.4oz) it is an incredible bargain.  More of these!!

Hazy brown pour, lasting creamy tan head keeps going and going.  Aroma of raisin, prune, dark candy.  Taste = aroma X 2, mild sweetness countered by punch of bitterness.  Very fizzy on the tongue, a bit too much for my taste.  Much what was expected with more complexity (+) and extra lively carbonation(-).  Would definitely drink this again.  Interesting!

Deep red pour, short-lived off-white head.  Aroma reminds me of being in a very old library, deliciously dusty/leathery/earthy.  Taste very complex, vinous, intense, smooth.  Provokes thoughtful contemplation.  Really.
Commercial deScription pretty much nails it.  Very decent brown ale. Light/medium body with clean finish makes for a great session beer.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Tumbler Autumn Brown Ale

review_blob: Fair amber ale, refreshing.  Cloudy amber/orange pour (draft), light malty aroma with spicy hops.  Taste like aroma.  Medium bitter with light body.
beer_name: Florida Beer Key West Sunset Ale

review_blob: Consumed from bottle at outdoor fundraising event.  Aroma a bit yeasty, bread and chocolate.  Taste of sweet roasty malt, distinct bitterness yet not biting.  Medium body, smooth mouthfeel with average carbonation.   Everything I expect in a decent Red Ale.
beer_name: Rogue Dry Hopped St. Rogue Red Ale

review_blob: Brilliant orange/copper pour.  Two finger creamy off-white head diminishing to short, but lasting froth.  Abundant sticky lacing.  Aroma of some citrus and pine, strong caramel, with some ethanol as it warms.  Big sweet caramel taste, yet bracing citrus/pine bitterness along with some ethanol.  Medium full body with oily texture.  Steady carbonation rising from bottom of glass.  Long bitter finish leaves mouth somewhat dry (another please?).  A different take on the Imperial IPA, and a damn fine brew.

Consumed from bottle at an outdoor fundraising event.  Aroma malty, spicy/earthy hops.  Light sweetness with medium bitterness.  Light body yet dense texture, carbonation lively.  Brief bitter finish.  For some reason this beer reminds me of fall - standing ext to an evening bonfire as the leaves are falling.  Very enjoyable.

Deep reddish copper pour, short but lasting creamy head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of light roast malt, earthy/woody/floral hops.  Signifiicant bitterness, well rounded and ultimately pleasant.  Malt sweetness well balanced.  Medium body, light carbonation, Full mouthfeel.  Lingering malty finish polished by wspy hop bitterness.  A really different IPA, in a very good and interesting way.  Look forward to 6-pack packaging at summers end.  Must buy again!!

Pours the darkest of browns, short-lived tan head.  Primary aroma of chocolate malt, a little roasty, underlying spiciness.  Taste also primarily weighted toward chocolate malt, light roast character with a twang of something slightly sour and spicy.  Medium body yet thin texture, average carbonation .  Very good past the lips, over the tongue, then a half-hearted slap of sour twang to remember it by as it goes down the hatch.  Decently balanced stout, but cant quite aquire the taste fior this one.

Pour is burnt orange in color, a short off-white head settles quickly to a thin cap of foam.  Haze disappears with increasing temperature.  Muted toasty aroma, overcome by citrus and piney hops, with a detectable alcohol presence.  Heavily bitter, surprisingly without real harshness, with a peek of residual sweetness.  Medium body, thick oily texture.  Lightly carbonated with a long bitter finish.  Overall I find it a blunt instrument for the tastebuds, though very interesting.  I can not imagine this being paired with any food - a stand alone beer in my book.

Deep, deep red pour, creamy off-white, but non-persistent, head.  Aroma of chocolate with a bit of caramel.  Moderate taste of chocolate malt, a little roasty, nicely blended vanilla that doesnt stand out, but really seems to belong there.  Bittersweet.  Very thin body, goes down way too easily.  Good as is, yet could be great if strength added in each category.

Bright copper pour with thin fizzy head.  Very little aroma, what is there is bread, spicy hops and an ever so slight sour note.  Taste is similar to aroma, with some graininess.  Thin body, abrupt dry finish.   I am just not into this one.

Light golden, minimal white head that fades quickly.  Aroma lightly malty, overshadowed by light citrus/piney/grassy hops.  Taste is noticeably (yet lightly) bitter, with more of the hop presence.  Light body, thin texture, average carbonation, abrupt finish.  Mild all the way around.  I expected a bit more "WOW" factor, being an IPA.  However it is pleasantly drinkable, and likely an excellent "lawnmower " beer.

Reddish amber pour topped by thin, short-lived white head.  Aroma of nutty brown malt with slight spiciness.  Taste of sweet brown malt with just a hint of sourness.  Light body, thin texture, average carbonation with dry bitter finish.  Very sessionable.  Overall very good, will buy again.

Deep burnished gold fills the glass, topped by billowing creamy off-white head that lasts and lasts.  Aroma of rich citrus hop goodness.  First sip is a complex explosion of sweet malt, accompanied by bracing piney/citrusey delight.  A full palate indeed, thick and oily with lively-yet-soft effervescence that is pleasing to the depths of the soul.  Long, dry, bitter finish literally begs for more...more...MORE...

Clear golden yellow pour, white head quickly fading to a thin film.  Some lacing on sides of glass.  Aroma of floral, spicy hops with a grainy malt backdrop.  Taste is more of the same with a crisp bitterness.  Medium body, thin texture, low carbonation.  Dry, bitter finish.  Not too exciting but pleasantly drinkable.

Aroma of bread, cereal, a little spicy. Pour crystal golden clear, minimal snow white head.  Taste of light malt accented by spicy hop character.  Medium in sweetness & bitterness. Light body, thin slick feel, soft carbonation, long, bitter finish.  If this were a pale lager, I would say above average. Not to my taste, not likely to buy again.

Aroma bready, upstaged by citrus & earthy hops.  Appearance deep golden, crystal clear, white creamy head that rapidly diminishes to a thin film.  Light sweetness up front, medium-strong bitterness throughut.  Slightly salty.  Light body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish.  Welcome in my kennel anytime.
beer_name: Flying Dog Snake Dog IPA (2008 and later)

review_blob: Aroma complex, predominately hops as one would expect in an IPA.  Resin, grass, citrus, faintly woody. Brilliant clear amber, with persistent pillowy off-white head.  Much sticky lacing.  Taste is medium sweet, over an underlying heavy (but not harsh) bitterness.  Full body, oily texture, sticky, thick feel.  Soft carbonation, yet 1/4 inch head remains halfway down the glass. Pleasantly lingering bitter finish. Overall, very satisfying with unexpected aspects, such as the fullness of body and restrained citrus quality.  Good differences, which makes trying new brews so rewarding!

Bready aroma with a fresh lemon air.  Pour hazy golden, minimal white head.  Medium bitterness in taste. Palate medium to light body, thin feel, lively carbonation, bitter, long finish.  I find it overall a somewhat muted sensory experience, which is great when that it what the day calls for.

Pours brilliant pale gold, absolutely clear.  Smallish white head quickly receding to thin film.  Mildly sweet, bready aroma.  Taste is medium sweet with a kiss of bitterness.  Light body with light, fizzy carbonation.  Smooth texture with lingering sweet malt finish.  Overall not very exciting, but easily drinkable.
beer_name: Flying Dog Tire Bite Golden Ale

review_blob: Amber/orange pour with 1 finger eggshell head, much sticky lacing to the last drop.  Medium caramel malt aroma, overcome with citrus/earthy hops.  Taste is an explosion of everything that is good about beer!  Solid caramel/pale malt backbone, heavy dose of hops that are primarily citrus, but some English earthiness as well.  Bittersweet, with emphasis on the bitter.  Very well balanced nonetheless, not biting but smooth.  Really good stuff!

12 oz. bottle.  Amber pour, 1-finger head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of dark malts, lightly hoppy.  Flavor leans on malt profile - Munich/Vienna-like, darkr malt and hops subdued but present.  Medium body, oily slick palate, good cool-weather brew.

Draft, in Charlottesvile at The Boat House.  Amber pour with thick creamy head, lacing to the bottom of the glass.  Aroma citrusy-floral, lightly malty.  Flavor bracingly bitter (in a very good way), caramel malt with solid citrusy-piney hop presence.  Medium body, very satisfying.  Solid IPA.

22oz. bomber.  Hazy golden pour yielding aroma of orange, coriander, light hops and sweet malt.  Flavor more of the same, sweet yet dry finish. Low carbonation, short and short-lived head.  Would be ideal seaside session brew. Reminds me of the beach for some reason - good times!

Pitch black pour, fluffy dark tan head.  Head diminishes slowly, lots of lacing.  Aroma of anise, dark fruit, chocolate.  Aggressively flavorful, anise, chocolate, dark fruit, old leather, roasted malt.  Full mouthfeel, rich oily texture, mild alcohol warmth.  Wonderful brew!
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: Cloudy golden with creamy white head.  Aroma of yeast and clove.  Flavor of malty wheat, light clove and predominately banana - more so as it warms.  Light body, adequate bitterness.  Nicely done.

22oz. bomber. Slightly hazy golden pour with avreage off-white head.  Aroma abudantly floral, with some citrus and pine.  Solid malt backbone supports the incredibly complex hop character.  Virtually any deScriptor that can be applied to hops is in there.  Huge hop prescence,yet not stingingly bitter.  Sweet, oily, exceptionally pleasant.  I am seriously stocking up on this at the next opportunity.

Slightly hazy copper-orange pour.  Holding the pint glass up to sunlight, the top is orange fading to yellow-gold at the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is most definitely tropical fruits.  This is gonna be good... One-finger egshell head diminishes to a light blanket rather quickly.  There is sticky lacing.  The malt is nearly undetectable, except that there is something significant holding up this hop explosion - kind of like universal dark matter.  Flavor is a pleasant surprise of massive piney, citrusy hops, silky smooth indeed, with a noticeable but unobtrusive ethanolic heat.  I usually rate on the first impression, about 1/3 glass; this just keeps getting better with every sip.   Palte is medium full with oily texture (duh), soft carbonation, and relatively clean finish considering the hop  level.  Aftertaste is brief, yet begging for the next sip.  God bless and keep Three Floyds.

Malty caramel aroma wafts from the soft, creamy, eggshell head of this delicious deep brown dream.  By gosh, there IS a clear clarion call of hazelnut weaving through the tapestry of fine Wisconsin barley malts!  I have not had many nut brown ales, but it is difficult to imagine that there could be a finer example than Fat Squirrel, my newest friend.  Until we meet again...
beer_name: New Glarus Fat Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
